Award.AwardTitle: SODA Conference Student and Postdoc Travel Support

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports student and postdoctoral fellow attendance at the
SIAM-ACM Symposium on Discrete Algorithms (SODA), to take place during
January 5-8, 2020 in Salt Lake City, Utah. SODA is one of the few
major conferences with broad coverage of Theory of Computing and
Discrete Mathematics. SODA has a record of strongly encouraging
participation by students, for whom the conference serves as a valuable
educational experience, both for the technical content of the talks and
for the opportunities for networking that it provides. This award will
provide partial support to about 20 students/postdocs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this grant, written in my role as the SODA Steering Committee chair, is to assist students and postdoctoral fellows for travel to attend the Annual ACM-SIAM Symposium on Discrete Algorithms (SODA) 2020 at Salt Lake City.
The goal is to encourage and enable the participation of students and postdocs in cases where travel expenses would otherwise preclude their attendance. With particular priority given to support young scholars from under-represented groups, broadening the participation will benefit students in need as well as strengthen the long-term robustness and diversity of this top conference.
It has been a wonderful experience interacting with many talented young researchers in theoretical computer science (and their advisors) to understand their needs. I hope these experiences will contribute to future collaboration between NSF and TCS conferences.

Intellectual Merit:

With the rise of the Internet, Big Data and AI, computer science is now at the center of the many disciplines, from natural sciences to social sciences, from medicine to art, from engineering to policy. As these interactions emerge, theoretical computer scientists, particularly the younger generation, have taken great strides in advancing algorithmic/computational thinking beyond our traditional fields. The NSF travel award has been making direct contributions to this generation.

ACM-SIAM SODA is the premier conference in the field of discrete algorithms. Together with ACM STOC and IEEE FOCS, it is one of three major conferences in theoretical computer science. It is also the largest TCS conference. In a typical year, SODA has over 400 attendees. The field of algorithms is a vibrant one, with high participation rates from young researchers, and many papers with student authors. SODA has a wide coverage of algorithmic research and has continued to play instrumental roles in collaboration between TCS and discrete mathematics, with research problems connecting with almost all emerging fields of computing.

Because many advisors pleged support for their students --- particular those with paper(s) accepted ?-- in case they didn?t receive any travel award, we were able to partly support all students with papers in SODA 2020 who wanted to attend the conference. We are able to support many students (without papers) who attended SODA for the first time. Again, we thank many advisors and universities to work with us to co-support students, which enabled more young researchers to participate in this wonderful conference. In total, this NSF grant supported or partly supported 36 young scholars. We believe the interactive environment of SODA, where cutting-edge research and open problems are discussed, will further assist the awardees' engagement with a broad set of fundamental questions and ideas. With a strong aim to support young researcher from underrepresented groups and talented students beyond traditional TCS powerhouses, our goal is to broaden the participation to make SODA an even more robust primere TCS conference. We expect the research community to benefit in turn, as such junior researchers have contributed substantially to the growth of theoretical computer science over the years.

Broader Impacts:

This year, ACM SIGACT and our industry partners (IBM, Google, Microsoft) also contributed $16,000. In total, we received 65 applications, including students/postdocs outside the USA. The NSF grant was only used to support domestic applicants, while other funds were used to support both domestic and international applicants. The funds were widely distributed beyond just traditional TCS powerhouses (with awardees from 22 US universities).
The list of young scholars supported by this NSF grant includes one African American (giving first presentation at SODA), two Hispanic Americans (both presenting at SODA), and seven female computer scientists/mathematicians (three presenting at SODA). Working with NSF and young researchers in this selection process provided us valuable experience to be more proactive in reaching out to (1) Grace Hopper Celebration of Women in Computing, (2) CRA-W, (3) Hispanics in Computing, (4) iAAMCS (Institute for African-American Mentoring in Computing Sciences), and (5) TAPIA communities. These connections will also help us  to reach out to theoretical computer scientists more broadly about future NSF SODA travel grants. Many awardees will be future leaders in TCS. Several have already made breakthrough discoveries in algorithm design and computational complexity by solving long-term fundamental open questions. The NSF travel award, particularly at this stage of their professional career, are critical support to their growth. In addition to helping them to participate in the premier conferences to benefit them and the research community, the application process also helped them to recognize how much their research is supported by not just their advisors/institutes, but by society in large.

Acknowledgement: (1) Thanks all for help posting our message. (2) USC Computer Science Department?s business office provided complimentary support for managing this NSF grant, so that all funds have been used for student/postdoc travel to attend SODA. We greatly appreciate their contribution and generosity.
